33. Meanwhile, life continues to suck for the white working class, & Trump is too incompetent or too weak politically to do anything abt it.

31. One thing’s for sure. Saving the NEA will not save some arts groups. The problem is bigger. Much bigger.
30. With more demand, arts orgs would likely discover more freedom.
29. One could argue that millions spent by arts orgs would have been better spent hiring teachers to instill in children a love for arts.
28. Indeed, one could argue that demand would rise if the thousands of ppl people employed by nonprofits taught in public schools.
27. But access is no substitute for early exposure to the arts or for teaching kids how to experience the arts as part of their daily lives.
26. As $$$ for arts declined, arts groups rushed in to provide access for those who would not otherwise have it. Now we are where we are.
25. Arts orgs have been doing what public schools should have been doing but could not after $$$ for arts education increasingly dried up.
24. So the long-term solution is rebuilding demand.
23. Alas, there is probably no short-term solution. There’s too much supply and not enough demand for the arts.
22. With or without the NEA, museums, orchestras and other groups will remain between a rock and a hard place.
21. So it doesn’t matter much what happens in this new scuffle over the NEA.
20. leaving less money for everyone else to spend on concert tickets, and leaving arts organizations in thrall to the whims of rich donors.
19. More fundamentally, federal tax policy has since the 1980s redistributed wealth upward to the top 1 percent, ....
18. Arts orgs, struggling to absorb the growing surplus of art school and conservatory graduates, compete for a shrinking pool of money.
17. The future for the arts is bleak. Colleges and universities continue to churn out artists into an already saturated labor market.
16. Outreach may have some impact, but in the long run, not much.
15. That is the hope, and while hope is a priceless commodity, it cannot overcome the overwhelming evidence pointing in the other direction.
14. The conventional wisdom is that educational outreach funded by foundations or public agencies will cultivate audiences of the future.
13. The heads of arts groups tend to avoid thinking about this as a vicious downward spiral.
12. That has meant educational outreach and endless grant applications to funders like the NEA.
11. As elderly patrons die, younger patrons usually do not replace them. That has forced arts groups to seek alternative revenues.
10. Despite such efforts, their audiences continue to grow older and grayer.
9. Arts organizations labor mightily to provide access to world-class programming to ppl, esp. kids, who might not otherwise have access.
8. In the economy of the arts, there is too much supply, not enough demand.
7. But even if the NEA survives, arts organizations face a future fraught with structural problems with no obvious solutions.
6. Public funding is critical to operations even though the amount may be as little as $10,000.
5. Such groups live within razor-thin margins between surplus and deficit. They can tap their board of directors only so many times.
4. But news of the president’s slash-and-burn budget has rattled arts organizations, especially small ones.
3. Republicans have threatened the NEA before. It may weather this storm, too.
2. Trump aims to eliminate NEA, NIH & host of Great Society programs costing a fraction of budget, about $2.5B, that enrich our society.
